subject: Redfish Telemetry Interface Design Proposal patchset2 with updates from all comments to patchset1 and improved formatting for reading raw .md file

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

The Telemetry and Health Monitoring WG has discussed using Redfish as the 
external interface for accessing telemetry metric reports (push or pull).
This design proposal is primarily meant to address the Redfish interface
and not the backend collectors.

nit: or ?
Done
How would a more complex algorithm be represented? e.g. a moving window average.

The filter algorithm is specified in the CalculationAlgorithm property which is
an Enum in Redfish.  Unfortunately, you cannot add oem values to an Enum.
Currently, only Average, Minimum, and Maximum  is defined in the enum.
We can add more filters to Redfish -- they take additional enum values easily.
I think Redfish should also add "OEM" to the CalculationAlgorithm property, and
then support a consistent way to specify an OemCalculationAlgorithm property
similar to how OEM Custom Privileges were done.
In the current model, you would just leave the filter undefined which is not good.
As I look at the model, I'm finding several issues like this that can be fixed quickly.

I put an issue in at Redfish forum.
should address next week.
They indicated they were not expecting filters other than max, min, average, but they are willing to define a standard way to express one
Are the other filters a [OEM] ?.. What other algo do we think we could make it a standard ?

The Redfish forum approved my request to add "OEM" to the standard filter enum, 
and then add an oem property that could identify the filter by stringName 
modified by the OEM's name.
The Redfish forum has not had any proposals to add standard filter algorithms other than the
current Average, Maximum, and Minimum.
They had an example mockup however where they calculate exhaust temperature based on fan speed, power consumption, and ambient temperature.  The math is actually quite complex, but would only be described in an OEM description property.
btw, I thought you mentioned there are some early implementations of this ?. or did I hear it wrong ?

Dell will include Telemetry in its iDRAC release that ships later this year.
I assume HPE and other are also working on implementations.
Intel has indicated they have an implementation that they propose porting to OpenBMC
So the ones collected by "collectd" are in rr format. How can we convey those here - We need to extract 'em using rrd_ apis

Metric data collected by collectd will need to be converted to JSON Redfish TelemetryReport format.  collectd has "write plugins" to output data in rrd or cvs formated files, or can write to redis or MangoDB, or can send to a web service using http using putval formatted data.

A RedfishTelemetryService will need to process metric reports as they are generated by the backend, format the reports, and then log or push the reports based on the Redfish Telemetry configuration

Correction here:  The Metric Report Definition can fully define what is in the report.
It can specify: 
 1) a list of any properties in the Redfish model (standard or oem properties),
 2) calculated properties where the result is not stored as a property
     (such as max CPU temp over all cpus for the day)
 3) and it "can" define an array of "oem MetricIds with values" 
(where the only thing that tells a client what the data means is the MetricId
 which could be described in some other oem document.)

So think about MetricDefinitions as (primarily) additional metadata that describes
metric report properties (even if they are in the standard model) for a 
client to understand data returned in the report better, and how to display or
use the data (eg units, range, isLinear, etc)

update: after reviewing with Redfish forum, the concensus intent is that the MetricReport does indeed tag each Metric Property with a MetricId that matches the Id of the corresponding Metric Definition.   so best practices is what I originally stated.

Regarding whether to create sensors / properties for any metric data we want to send out:
 - As I noted, Redfish currently does not require this,
 - Some companies wanted to require it, and will implement oem properties for any
   metric data they return in a report.
 - Some companies were strongly against requiring properties and will send reports that 
   include data along the lines of "3)" above.  
 - So the model accommodates both. 
 - Long-term, this may change. 

Likewise, Redfish does not require ANY MetricDefinitions. 
 - MetricDefinitions are additional metadata for clients.
 - the metric report definition (it turns out) does NOT identify properties based on the
   MetricDefinition Id (or link) in the MetricDefinitionsCollection.  
    -The Report Definition only references Redfish Properties, or allows the
      implementation to just send data out under a made-up MetricId ("3)" avove).

We should have discussion on this and decide what the OpenBMC model should be.
 - At first, I was thinking it is more Redfish-like to define any data included in a
   Metric Report in the MetricDefinitions Collection, and then let the
   MetricReportDefinition just reference the MetricDefinition Ids.
 - This is do-able, but it turns-out that the MetricIds used by MetricReportDefinition 
   are not (necessarily) (or required to be) (unfortunately) mapped to
   the MetricDefinitions.
 - It looks like the most clean to understand (and probably most inter-operable) 
   (and probably the most testable and debug-able) implementation is to make any 
   metrics that are included in a report a Redfish property.
   Could be a standard property or oem property anywhere in the schema
    - This would make it easy to access the data with http GET independent of 
      the logging and Push implementation
 - It likely will make integration with backend collectd easier.
   -- if the backend saves any collected data in Dbus, the Redfish frontend 
      could handle the logging and pushing
In the recent email from Kun, it mentions no D-Bus plugin for collect. Please correct me if i'm wrong Kun.

I thought originally Kun has indicated the plan was to have a d-bus plugin but the discussion ended with no plugin I think.

Also, regarding my comment on MetricIds in MetricReports.
The best practice recommendation is to indeed include MetricId's in the MetricReport that indeed identifies which MetricDefinition is associated with that metric.
So OpenBMC should indeed include  identify all Metric properties in a MetricDefinition and reference those as Id in the Metric Report.
I really appreciate your effort in explaining the redfish telemetry model and the supporting concepts here.
For my education: How does this work ?. Does it create a session on need, POST, close ?
yes. when the BMC wants to post a metric out, it creates an http session with the configured client and sends the report out, and then closes the session.
Does this use websockets ?

It uses "Server Side Events" (SSE).  Not web-sockets.  they are similar.
SSE is one-direction, HTTP-only protocol and simplier.
see: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5195452/websockets-vs-server-sent-events-eventsource for a good discussion on the difference.

AvgConsumedWatts ?

Average Consumed Watts := Average Power Consumption in Watts
in this example AveConsumedWatts is the average power over the last hour
arrived at by averaging the readings from current power draw "PowerConsumedWatts" 
over the last hour

So this returns a specific metric report definition with a link to the metric report as part of "MetricReport" property.

Wonder why it says predefined metric report ?.. 

Also, in line: 245, are we directly getting a report which if defined here as part of "MetricReport" for example ?

correction-typo:  GET MetricReportDefinition returns a specific MetricReportDefinition
  (not a MetricReport)
Do we also need a PATCH for MetricDefinition ?. For example:  the "SensingInterval"

correct.   Sample interval (SensingInterval), and the sliding calculation duration interval (CalculationTimeInterval) are properties that would make the most sense to be settable.  Units is also settable, but not sure we would really want to open that for clients to tweak.
I was thinking for step-1  we would not make metricDefinition properties settable, but we could do the intervals.
Also, is it possible to PATCH a trigger. For example: If we need to say [Log , Transmit] / DwellTimes etc... Are these settable properties at all ?

yes. several Trigger properties are writable including:
 - the Threshold Reading, crossing direction, and dwell Time for a trigger associated with a
   threshold or discrete sensor to activate
 - current model doesn't allow setting the action (send event or metricReport), but that
   might be an error
Avg ?
Done
nit: Missing )

I like this...  However, who would host these D-Bus properties ?.  Since this is specific to a particular MetricDefinition/Report, this can not go into settings. -or- it can still go into settings, with a parameter to mention the particular metric***

yes it could go into settings with parameter to link it to a metric definition
In fact Redfish supports the concept where a resource can return annotations indicating that a property is part of a metric report e.g. in the Chassis / Power resource inserting:
PowerConsumedWatts@metricmetadata  which indicates that PowerConsumedWatts is in the MetricDefinitions collection.

Q1: Is there a way to ensure this at a compile time ?

Q2: I have this use case:; I need to report a PMIC data periodically.. So I will have a back-end that can periodically read that and store it in a file.. How can I feed that into this framework ?

I'm not sure how to ensure it automatically but maybe there is a way.
For starters, the config file can just describe what the metric report contains.
I figured that the backend would need to call the Redfish Metric Report handler that would send the report out or log it based on the config file settings.
This would need a restart of collectd service

dynamic client driven definition of metric reports is complicated.
Initial implementations to my knowledge are not supporting this.

See my long comment in background.
If we save collected data in DBus, Redfish could more easily model any data in the 
reports as a Redfish property and could get whatever data it wanted from DBus to include
in the report based on the MetricReportDefinition JSON file.  
Collectd could be saving more or less than Redfish supports and things could still work.
I believe, the approach was to save it in a RR file
typo: connectd --> collectd. Tomorrow, if we change the collector, does it need a change into this layer ?. or something that we need to provide as a config ?
I know @ratagupt was doing something on these lines.. I will subscribe him into this review.

Ack
as a ?
composed of a

We have considered this option, but it depends on having a fast link for transferring the file out (well, if the file is big), whereas having a dedicated interface can limit the query to the *last* entries of RRD files.
I see you listed several options in the connectd design
Ack
Do you have one already ?
no  I was referring to the collectd design doc

As we are introducing Redfish Telemetry model for the first time, Could you recomment on how we can verify. For eg. Can we use IPMI ? or other interfaces whether data what we had collect is correct etc..

Good question. In fact the Push delivery may be the more complicated thing to get
working reliably. I have added some add additional discussion in "Background and References" 
under "The Redfish Telemetry model supports the following features",
where I explain that we can decide to implement readable metric properties for
any metric results that we want to include in a report.  Redfish does not require it,
but if we went that approach, we could more easily read the metrics directly using other
protocols, and we could 1st verify that we could PULL them with Redfish with http GET.
ok
Ack

Thank you for your commit Paul! Please follow https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/ for commit messages.
The commit msg should follow:

summary, blank line, then 1 or lines of detail. E.g. 

Summary

detail line
detail line
detail line
...
proposed
